title: Ayrshire Coastal Path and Map Walking Route

images.title: Mary and Angus Hogg / Maidenhead Bay View, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Maidenhead Bay View. Looking towards Maidenhead Bay and the caravan site at the end of the beach. Viewed from a barley field above the village on a fine February afternoon.

images.title: Mary and Angus Hogg / Turnberry Bay View, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Turnberry Bay View. The northern end of Turnberry Bay, viewed where a small unnamed burn enters the sea. Recent winds and tides had covered the beach on the far side with seaweed and debris, in contrast with the clean conditions in the foreground.

images.title: Billy McCrorie / Ballantrae Bay, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Ballantrae Bay. Lovely view of the bay, on the far left is Bennane Hill and on the right Knockdolian Hill

images.title: Tony Page [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Troon Lifeboat Station, troon Harbour

images.title: Chris Wimbush / River Ayr Way at Ayr, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: River Ayr Way at Ayr

images.title: wfmillar / Irvine Bay(south), via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Irvine Bay(south)

images.title: wfmillar / South Bay Ardrossan, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: South Bay Ardrossan. Arran in the background. Barony St. John's church to the left.

description: A walk along the beautiful Ayrshire Coast from Glenapp Kirk, just north of Stranaraer, to Skelmorlie, near Greenock. The route passes Ayr, Prestwick, Saltcoats, Troon and Largs. As well as the fabulous coastal scenery there is the beautiful backdrop of the mountains of Arran across the Firth of Clyde to enjoy. There is also a variety of wildlife including 135 species of bird, seals, otters, roe deer and foxes. Other highlights include the dramatic Culzean Castle Country Park. Here you'll find an 18th century castle perched on a clifftop on the Ayrshire coast. It's well worth exploring the extensive grounds containing lush woodland, landscaped gardens. In Ayr the route links with the River Ayr Walk. The route follows the whole length of the River Ayr from the coast to the source at Glenbuck Loch. The Ayrshire Coastal Path is waymarked with a green and white disc.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: In Largs you could take a small detour to climb to the excellent viewpoint and Iron Age Hillfort at Knock Hill. Also near Largs you can take a detour from the route to pick up the popular Fairlie Glen Circular Walk. It's a delightful walk with babbling streams, woodland trails, open glens, photogenic waterfalls and fine coastal views.
